dances.name: Dance of the Flyers
dances.description: Ancient ritual where dancers descend from a tall pole while spinning, symbolizing the connection between heaven and earth.

details.story: Originating from the Totonac region, this dance represents the four cardinal directions and the elements. Each flyer spins 13 times, totaling 52 spins, equivalent to a Mesoamerican calendar cycle.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: Colorful costumes with traditional embroidery and headdresses of sacred bird feathers.

elements.title: Music
elements.text: Reed flute and drum marking the ceremonial rhythm as the flyers descend.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Cyclical renewal, prayer for rain and fertility for crops.

dances.name: Dance of the Little Black Ones
dances.description: Dance expression combining African and indigenous elements, characterized by its energy and contagious rhythm.

details.story: This dance emerged during colonial times as a form of cultural resistance. Dancers with black masks represent the fusion of African traditions brought by slaves with pre-Hispanic rituals.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: Carved wooden masks, costumes with mirrors and bells that mark the rhythm.

elements.title: Movement
elements.text: Energetic foot stomping and rapid spins demonstrating physical skill.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Cultural syncretism, resistance and celebration of mestizo identity.

dances.name: Dance of the Santiago
dances.description: Theatrical representation dramatizing the battle between good and evil, with roots in evangelization.

details.story: The dance narrates the battle between Apostle James, representing Christianity, and characters symbolizing opposing forces. It's a manifestation of religious syncretism in the region.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: Cardboard and plaster armor, wooden swords and masks identifying each character.

elements.title: Movement
elements.text: Martial and choreographed, simulating battle scenes with ritual precision.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Struggle between worldviews, faith and preservation of community traditions.

dances.name: Dance of the Michaels
dances.description: Ceremonial dance dedicated to Archangel Michael, protector against evil forces.

details.story: In San Juan Tahitic, this dance is performed during patron saint festivals. The Michaels, led by the Archangel, fight against devils and evil forces in a choreography full of symbolism.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: White tunics with red capes, angel masks and golden crowns.

elements.title: Music
elements.text: Violins and guitars accompanying songs in Nahuatl and Spanish.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Spiritual protection, purification and community renewal.

dances.name: Dance of the Quetzals
dances.description: Spectacular dance where multicolored headdresses spin creating a hypnotic visual mosaic.

details.story: Inspired by the sacred bird of Mesoamerica, this dance honors the quetzal as a symbol of freedom and divine connection. The spins represent celestial movements and the rotation of the universe.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: Circular headdresses with colored feathers that spin creating spectacular visual effects.

elements.title: Movement
elements.text: Synchronized spins and complex steps requiring years of training.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Mesoamerican worldview, cosmic cycles and relationship with nature.

dances.name: Dance of the Bullfighters
dances.description: Festive representation of bullfighting adapted to local tradition with humor and satire.

details.story: This dance emerged as a humorous critique of Spanish bullfighting. Local 'bullfighters', with exaggerated movements, ridicule taurine solemnity while entertaining the community.

elements.title: Attire
elements.text: Costumes inspired by bullfighters but with local elements, comic masks and colorful capes.

elements.title: Movement
elements.text: Buffoonish steps, theatrical falls and choreographed confrontations with the 'bull'.

elements.title: Symbolism
elements.text: Social criticism, humor as resistance and cultural appropriation of external traditions.
